instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid spill
threads.message:
Having a no backlight issue on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board after liquid spill. No corrosion was present on the board as it was a really recent liquid spill. Cleaned the liquid spill residue, have chime and video signal but no backlight. 

The fuse is good.

I'm getting 0V on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>

When I test using diode mode... (red probe on ground and black on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> on the LCD connector) I get 1.180 without the display plugged in, and 0.009 when the display is plugged in..

Please excuse my lack of experience, but that does that mean my display is bad? 
Also isn't the diode mode measurement on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> supposed to be .5something if there are no issues with the backlight circuit? 
I'm currently diagnosing it so if anybody has an answer please let me know.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid spill
threads.message: Diode mode test on the fuse is 0.146

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight after liquid spill
threads.message: There is obviously a short in the LCD or cable or LCD connector you plug it in and there is a short. This will also 100% kill the backlight fuse if the LCD is still displaying an image.
